title-group.article-title: World City Typologies and National City System Deterritorialisation: USA, China and Japan

author-notes.corresp: Xiulian Ma is in the Department of Social and Cultural Studies, Chinese Academy of Governance, No. 6 Changchunqiao Rd, Haidian District, Beijing, 100089, China. E-mail: echolley@gmail.com.
Michael Timberlake is in the Department of Sociology, University of Utah, 380 S 1530 East, Salt Lake City, Utah, 84112, US. E-mail: timber@soc.utah.edu.

abstract.p: The research constitutes the first effort to test the claim found in the world city theoretical literature that, as world cities strengthen ties with each other, their linkages with their countries’ hinterlands and national urban systems will weaken. This research offers a more nuanced exploration of this hypothesis by taking into account variation in the nature of the state across countries in which world cities are located as well as the source of global capital in the world cities. Specifically, the research reported here suggests that three types of world cities—market-centred bourgeois world cities (MWC), state-centred political bureaucratic world cities (SWC) and dual-role world cities (DWC)—entail different deterritorialisation outcomes. Three countries that have prototypical global cities—Japan (SWC), China (DWC) and the US (MWC) are compared, applying longitudinal network modelling to relational data on national city networks. From 1993 to 2007, more globally connected MWCs weakened their national ties. In contrast, higher global status has no significant effect on the integration of SWCs or DWCs with their national urban systems. This indicates that the type of state, but not the source of capital, conditions whether the world city will deterritorialise vis-à-vis its national city system.

body.p: As cities rise in prominence in the global economy, the relations between these ‘world cities’ and their territorial states becomes an increasingly salient question for researchers and policy-makers. The ‘world city thesis’ (WCT) (Friedmann 1986, 1995; Sassen 1991, 2000) argues that, as world cities, such as New York, Tokyo and Shanghai, strengthen ties with each other, their linkages with their countries’ hinterlands and national urban systems will weaken. The logical outcome of this process over time is that world cities will replace the territorial economy of nation-states as the basic geographical building blocks of world capitalism (see Brenner, 1998, for a summary).

Scholars holding a more state-centred view disagree. Hill and Kim (2000, p. 2167) found that Tokyo’s “economic base, spatial organisation and social structure” did not converge with that of New York or London—the WCT’s prototype leading cities. Thus, logically, this deteriorating relationship between world cities and their national urban system will also only hold for New York and London, cities that are under a laissez-faire state, but not Tokyo, a world city under a developmental state. However, the exception to this is that no researcher has yet empirically tested this deterritorialisation hypothesis, largely due to the tremendous difficulty in conducting such an empirical test. This leaves this key WCT hypothesis in an un-challenged position.

This research presents the first effort to address this empirical inadequacy. The WCT is full of network imagery when it argues that there is an antagonistic relationship between world cities and national city systems through weakening ties with the latter. It is precisely this network imagery that poses a daunting challenge to the conventional empirical approach that focuses only on attributes of cities. Here, we match the network theorising of the world city approach with network methodology, applying a longitudinal network model to relational data.

Furthermore, we employ two strategic developmental axes (domestic vs foreign capital and developmental vs laissez-faire state) to classify cities further, thus identifying three types of world cities: market-centred bourgeois world cities (MWC), state-centred political bureaucratic world cities (SWC) and dual-role world cities (DWC). Each may entail different deterritorialisation outcomes.

sec.title: Weakened National Ties?
sec.p:
One of the major world city theorists, Sassen (1991, 2000) argues that as world cities become more globally prominent, they will become deterritorialised from the states in which they are located. One manifestation is at the national city system level. That is, as world cities strengthen ties with each other, their linkages with their countries’ national urban systems will weaken (Sassen, 1991). World cities
do not simply compete with each other for the same business. There is an economic system that rests on distinct types of locations and specializations each city represents. Furthermore, it seems likely that the strengthening of transnational ties between the leading financial and business centers is accompanied by a weakening of the linkages between each of these cities and its hinterland and national urban system (Sassen, 2000, p. 55).

Sassen’s statement implies a network imagery (also developed by others such as Castells, 1996, and Massey, 2007 in which the global economic power has increasingly concentrated in a few interconnected cities, while rendering the rest of the system disconnected. The new economic geography (NEG) (see Fujita and Krugman, 2004; Krugman, 1999) argument that globalisation leads to a core–periphery structure between regions also validates the WCT.

As leading global cities like New York, London and Tokyo consolidated their positions in their national urban systems, a discontinuity developed between these cities and the rest of their urban systems—for example, some 31 per cent of all producer service jobs in the UK are concentrated in London, but are underrepresented in the other major urban centres in the country. This discontinuity indicates that a world city could become a control centre rather than a service centre, monopolising its hinterland and growing at its expense. This is similar to what dependency researchers found for primate cities decades ago (Browning, 1958; Cornelius, 1975; Portes, 1976; Walton, 1976). Primate city systems, by definition, lack medium cities to connect regional systems to the national economy (Johnson, 1970), which in turn, generates various adverse outcomes including increasing regional and class inequality (Smith, 1985). Similarly, world cities have caused increased regional disparity and spatial polarisation, as Friedmann (1986) and Sassen (2000) argue.

sec.title: MWC vs SWC
sec.p: However, developmentalists in world city research (Hill and Fujita, 2003; Hill and Kim, 2000; Jacobs, 2003; Saito, 2003) contest this uniform view of world cities. They dichotomise world cities into market-centred bourgeois world cities (MWC) and state-centred political bureaucratic world cities (SWC). Prototypical MWCs are New York and London—in the North Atlantic—where self-regulated markets prevail under liberalism. Prototypical SWCs are Tokyo and Seoul—in the East Pacific—where strategic national interests under developmentalism dominate. The two types of world cities drastically differ from each other in various ways (Table 1).

sec.p: This dichotomisation implies that MWCs but not SWCs may weaken ties with their national companion cities as the two types of world cities embody global control capacity differently. The global control capacity for MWCs is offered through financial and producer service firms, as well as the concentration of multinational corporation (MNCs) functions, such as headquarter functions. For SWCs, it resides in the policy networks in which ministries are tied to businesses through banks and public corporations. This is largely because, according to the variety of capitalism theory, a liberal market economy achieves competitiveness through market deregulation, while a co-ordinated market economy—the category into which a developmental state largely falls—relies on networks (Hall and Soskice 2001). In turn, within the cities, MWCs see significant replacement of manufacturing by both advanced and lower-level service sectors, which generate wealth concentration, income bipolarity and spatial segregation. In contrast, changes are not as disruptive and pronounced in SWCs.

sec.title: A Dual-Role City
sec.p:
However, neither the SWC nor the MWC fully captures Friedmann’s notion of dual-role world cities
Essential to make the world safe for capital, they also articulate given national economies with the world system. As such, they have considerable salience for national policy-makers who must respond to political imperatives that are only coincidentally convergent with the interests of the transnationals. World cities lie at the juncture between the world economy and the territorial nation-state (Friedmann and Wolff, 1982, p. 312).

For the dual-role functions—i.e. to “make the world safe for capital” and to “articulate given national economies”—it seems that MWCs are much more attuned to the former. New York and London deregulated their markets so as to allow global firms to conduct business there. The city is the global basing-point for the operations of stateless MNCs (Hill and Kim, 2000). Not only does it not “articulate given national economies with the world system”, but it even grows at the expense of it. In contrast, Tokyo (and Seoul) are the national basing-points for the global operations of Japanese (and South Korean) MNCs (Fujita and Hill, 1995). As global capital is also domestic, serving global capital is the same as articulating the national economy. A dual role has combined into a single one: articulating “given national economies with the world system”.

Two factors jointly turn New York/London or Tokyo/Seoul into a single-role world city: the source of global capital; and the state’s capacity, especially its developmental capacity. A combination of external global capital and low state capacity (such as the neo-liberal state) gives rise to MWCs like New York or London, which serve only the global accumulation logic. On the other hand, domestically born global capital and high state capacity (such as the developmental state) give rise to SWCs like Tokyo or Seoul, which serve only the national economy.1

Finally, a combination of both high state capacity and external global capital gives rise to a dual-role world city (DWC), serving both global capital and the national economy simultaneously. For example, Shanghai is under the imperative of the accumulation regimes of both global capital and territorial state. Shanghai has become a global city as it has attracted significant amounts of global capital flows into the city, up to 15 per cent of the foreign direct investment that China has received. It endeavours to “make the world safe for capital”. At the same time, Shanghai serves as the growth pole to open up the Yangtze River Delta to the world economy. The Chinese developmental states—both central and local—are planning to build Shanghai into a global financial centre (Cai and Sit, 2003). Shanghai presents itself as a case in which two contradictory roles—serving global capital and articulating national economy—are both managed successfully.

Finally, the combination of domestically born global capital with low state capacity will also give rise to a DWC in principle, but it would quickly devolve into cities like New York or London, serving only global capital. Absent the state as a significant player that purposefully directs domestically born global capital to serve the national economy, the imperative of global accumulation regime will soon dominate via the market (Figure 1).

sec.title: Deterritorialisation Outcomes
sec.p: Different types of world cities entail different deterritorialisation outcomes. Deterritorialisation, by definition, is the process in which the territorial state increasingly cedes to transnational corporations its control of the accumulation process on its territory. With respect to city systems, deterritorialisation mainly concerns the ties between world cities and their national urban systems.

First of all, different deterritorialisation outcomes follow from the different global control capacities that each type of world city embodies. MWCs rely on advanced producer services in a deregulated market to achieve their global control; SWCs rely on the policy network to realise their global control; and DWCs utilise both. This gives rise to different interaction patterns between global cities and their less globally important national companions. The growth of advanced producer services in MWCs precisely feeds on the further decentralisation of manufacturing around the country or even around the world. Moreover, even headquarters functions are decoupled to nearby cheaper locations, thinning out the direct linkages between MWCs and their hinterlands that are co-ordinated through market mechanisms. In contrast, as the global control capacity of SWCs resides in a policy network, headquarters functions have to locate close to the policy network in order to have easy access to it. Since the network is the main co-ordination mechanism, the non-global localities have to maintain close contact with the global cities in order to access functions there. On the other hand, DWCs combine advanced producer service firms and policy networks as platforms for global control. In DWCs, while the operation of global capital is managed via an advanced producer service complex, territorial state controlled resources are accessed through government policy networks. MNCs and territorial states collaborate and bargain with each other. DWCs’ global–local interaction patterns are somewhat between that of MWCs and SWCs.

The control of capital also plays a role in this deterrritorialisation process. The deregulated neo-liberal state ‘accommodates’ the free-flowing global capital that has little to do with the country’s overall national development trajectory. In contrast, a developmental state puts strict control over global capital flows in order to integrate this productive force into its own territorial accumulation trajectory. Moreover, the developmental state has developed the structural capability to do so via policies, administrative protocols and regulatory mechanisms.

sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: The three types of world cities entail different deterritorialisation outcomes. First, with both external global capital and low state capacity serving as centrifugal forces for global–local intercity interaction, MWCs will deterritorialise

list-item.p: H1: As MWCs become more global, their ties with their national companions will weaken.

sec.p: Secondly, SWCs are unlikely to deterritorialise with both domestic-originated global capital and a strong developmental state serving as centripetal forces for global–local intercity interaction:

list-item.p: H2: As SWCs become more global, their ties with their national companions will not weaken.

sec.p: Thirdly, the degree of deterritorialisation for a DWC is somewhere in between that of an SWC and an MWC. The centrifugal force of external global capital is counterbalanced by the centripetal force of a strong developmental state. As a result, phenomenal world city growth, national economic development and increased regional disparity are concomitant, as is true of Shanghai (Yu and Wei, 2003). Therefore, we hypothesise

list-item.p: H3: As DWCs become more global, their ties with their national companions will weaken, but to a lesser degree than MWCs.

sec.title: Data and Methods
sec.p: The research compares three countries that have prototypical global cities—i.e. Japan (SWC), China (DWC) and the US (MWC), in order to decide how deterritorialisation effects vary.

In the past decade, world city researchers have adopted a relational/network approach (for example, Alderson et al., 2010; Beaverstock et al., 1999; Mahutga et al., 2010; Smith and Timberlake, 1993). This empirical approach establishes roles in hierarchical urban networks on the basis of patterns of between-city linkages and flows—“flows of population, goods, services, information and ideas, and/or by direct organization contral” (Smith and Timberlake, 1993, p. 189).

sec.title: Dependent Variables
sec.p: The national urban system is organised within a territorial state, integrating the country administratively, economically, culturally and so on. We use air passenger flows as the empirical basis for measuring the national urban system. Air passenger flows are widely used in mapping city networks (Keeling, 1995; Matsumoto, 2004; O’Connor, 2003; Rimmer, 1998; Smith and Timberlake, 1995, 2001, 2002; Witlox et al., 2004). Using travellers among cities is especially good at capturing the flow of the businessmen, bureaucrats and professionals, although certainly tourists and family visitors also get into the mix.

One caveat with using air passenger flow data to model an urban network is that the distance between given pairs of cities determines the likelihood of whether travellers between them will go by air or via other means. Thus the degree of connectivity between geographically proximate city pairs is likely to be underestimated with the air passenger flow data. The intercity distance is much smaller in Japan than in the US or China.2 As a result, Japan relies more heavily on rail than on airplanes for intercity travel. In contrast, flight is at least as equally important as rail travel in China or automobile in the US. In other words, a smaller proportion of intercity travel is captured by flight in Japan than in the US or in China. Due to the unavailability of passenger flow data by other modes of transport, this is the best we can do, as intercity flow data are quite rare. In any case, the effect of underestimating the connectivity between proximate cities in Japan would not bias the findings in favour of the hypothesis.

Chinese city system data cover the 43 largest cities (1992, 2000 and 2003) and contain more than 90 per cent of the overall air passenger flows within China, according to the General Administration of Civil Aviation of China (CAAC), the agency which provided the data. The US air passenger flow data (1993, 2000 and 2007) are provided by the US Department of Transportation’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics. The data consist of passenger flows between origin and destination cities based on a 10 per cent sample survey of the actual tickets. This analysis includes a sample of 100 cities that had the highest passenger flow in 1993. The Japanese air passenger flow data (1993, 2000 and 2007) are from the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism. The bureau publishes yearly statistics on the actual passenger flows between airports, which the analysis aggregates to the city level. The sample includes 58 cities, which contain 95 per cent of the overall air passenger flows in Japan.

sec.title: Global City Status
sec.p: Following Alderson and Beckfield (2004), the analysis identifying world cities’ position in the global city system uses data on the location of headquarters and subsidiaries of multinational corporations (MNCs). Of various world city measures developed in the past decade, the MNCs’ location network is the one most directly linked theoretically to the command-and-control functions generated by global capital (Derudder, 2006).

These data are from Directory of Corporate Affiliation from the LexisNexis Corporation. The data cover three years: 1993, the earliest year for which electronic data were available; and 2000 and 2007. This dataset is not limited to the Fortune Global 500. In 1993, it included 15 580 parent companies, as well as 13 090 cities. In 2000 and 2007, the number of parent companies increased to 22 081 and 24 000 respectively, and to 15 169 and 15 007 cities. A city’s global status is measured by two centrality scores in the MNC-generated world city network—i.e. outdegree and indegree. In social network analysis, centrality assesses how important a city is in the network. ‘World city outdegree’ is the total number of subsidiaries a city established in other cities; ‘world city indegree’ is the total number of subsidiaries a city received from other cities.

sec.title: City-level Urban Population
sec.p: City-level urban population data are projected by the United Nations Population Division (United Nations, 2008). The world urbanisation prospect data published in 2007 only include those cities with populations larger than 750 000 people. The Population Division supplemented data for smaller cities included in our sample. The data are projected using the last two to three empirical data points (usually censuses). The effect of population is predicted to be significantly positive. The data is log transformed to reduce skewness.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The analysis uses longitudinal network modelling to examine how world cities’ status influences their connectivity changes in the national urban system. The longitudinal network model differs from other longitudinal models (such as the panel model) in a fundamental way. The latter models attribute data, asking questions such as: how will total air passengers departing from the city increase as NYC becomes more global? The longitudinal network approach models relational data, asking questions such as: how will New York’s degree of integration with other US cities change (in terms of increasing air passenger connections) as it becomes more globally networked? Although the panel models utilise strategies to control for potential correlations across time or/and space, they can not model relational data—the type of data that most closely fit theories about world and national city systems.

The longitudinal network model falls into the formal class of continuous time Markov processes (Snijders, Steglich, and Schweinberger 2007; Steglich, Snijders, and Pearson 2004), and observed networks are outcomes of a Markov process evolving in continuous time. Although the observations are made at three discrete time points, the network evolution is represented as the result of many (usually non-observed) small changes occurring between the consecutively observed networks—such as New York lost a tie to Salt Lake City, and Los Angeles established a tie to the NYC, and so on. Because the network changes only one tie at a time, the longitudinal network modelling has to model both the moment when a city ‘makes’ a change and the particular change that it ‘makes’—both of which depend on the network structure and on observed covariates (such as the world city status of both cities).3 Therefore, the longitudinal network modelling procedure includes two parts. First, it models ‘the particular change to make’, or the ‘microsteps’ made by the cities. The decision rule for making such micro steps is a random utility function. The utility function is: city i chooses the ‘best’ ties decision j by maximising

This utility function is the sum of: a deterministic utility function f, which indicates the city’s ‘satisfaction’ with the result of the decision depending on model parameter β; and a random distortion term U, which is assumed to have a standard Gumbel distribution (Snijders, Steglich, and Schweinberger, 2007). The focus of the modelling is on the first element, the deterministic utility function f, modelled as linear combinations of effects that express endogenous network dependence and exogenous covariates.

Secondly, it models the ‘moment when’ to make the change, or the timing of micro steps. At randomly determined moments t, city i has the opportunity to change a tie. The programme for this analysis is SIENA (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis). The model only reaches the stage of using binary network changes as a dependent variable and does not have the ability to use higher-ratio or interval levels of measurement. So we dichotomise the valued network into a network only with value 1 or 0, depending on whether the value of the tie is bigger than the mean of the network.

The dependent variable of the network model is the tie relation between any two cities. As the network is binarised, the tie relation represents whether the passenger flow between two cities is larger than the network average. The network modelling examines three basic covariates’ effects on this tie relation after controlling endogenous network dependence effects—two endogenous network effects, density (outdegree) effect and reciprocity effect,4 must always be controlled. The three basic covariate effects are: ego effect—i.e. covariate effect on sending ties; alter effect—i.e. covariate effect on receiving ties; and similarity effects—i.e. covariate effect on nodes selecting each other (‘birds of a feather flock together’).5 Within each country, our findings examine how the rising global city status (measured by ‘world city outdegree’/‘world city indegree’) affects cities sending ties, receiving ties or selecting national city partners of relative similar global city status (see Table 2 in the results section).

sec.p: What is the likelihood, for instance, that, as Shanghai becomes more global, it will send or receive a tie from a national companion—say Xi’an—or that the two cities exchange ties with one another? Determining this requires considering the three covariate effects simultaneously.6 It is a log-odds ratio, which can be transformed back into an odds ratio through exponentiation. Rather than examining the interaction between any two cities’ national city partners, we dichotomise cities within each country by the national median level of globalisation, resulting in a globalised (High) group and a less globalised (Low) group. This allows us to examine the interaction patterns between/within the High and Low groups (see Table 3 in the results section). Since our categories are based on relative comparisons of cities within each country, the fact that there are differences across countries in the number of cities considered highly global by world-wide standards does not influence the results.

sec.p: The findings presented in Tables 2 and 3 thus represent the effects of changes in global network position on national partner ties. Again, the data measuring a city’s global standing are based on TNC headquarter–subsidiary networks world-wide and are based on one dataset. The data on national city networks are based on different national datasets measuring airline passenger flows. These data are not measured consistently across the three countries in that the US data are ‘de-hubbed’, based on tickets’ specification of origin and final destination. The data for Japan and China count passenger flows between airports and, thus, include transfer points (hubs). Ideally, we would want consistent measures across the three countries. However, since we are looking at global network effects on changes within nations, this measurement difference is not so serious.

sec.title: The United States
sec.p: Table 2 reports the results from the longitudinal network modelling for three countries: the US, China, and Japan. Models 1 and 2 examine the US data using world city indegree and outdegree centrality as the major predictors respectively. In model 1, the rate parameters, which represent the frequency of changes a city made from one period to another, are significant, indicating that each American city had about 27 opportunities for change during the first observation period (1993–2000) and 32 opportunities for change during the second observation period (2000–07). The endogenous network effect, density, measured as total outgoing ties for each city, has a significant negative parameter, as found in other longitudinal network modelling (Snijders, Steglich, and Schweinberger, 2007). This indicates that the cost of sending new ties is higher than its benefit, which is -5.87. As is the case in similar models, reciprocity has a highly significant positive effect, indicating that the benefits of reciprocating a tie are extremely high (-5.87 + 9.74 = 3.87.)

Model 1 also shows that, when controlling network effects and the urban population covariate effect, all three covariate effects (i.e. ego, alter and similarity) associated with the indegree centrality are significantly positive. The ego effect is the most dominant, with a magnitude 1.5 times that of the alter effect and 16 times that of the similarity effect. Its positive parameter implies the strong tendency of cities with higher indegree centrality to actively send out more ties. The positive parameter of alter effect (p < 0.5) implies that more globalised cities are more likely to receive ties, or to become more popular. Lastly, the significant similarity effect implies that actors prefer to tie to others with similar values on indegree centrality (p < 0.001). In sum, more globalised cities are more active, more popular and more likely to tie to others like them.

When a covariate occurs in several effects in the model, its effects can best be understood by considering all these effects simultaneously (Snijders, Steglich, Schweinberger and Huisman, 2007).7 As the indegree centrality covariate is highly skewed, we dichotomise the cities, by the median, into a globalised (High) group and a less globalised (Low) group, representing each with its own median. The purpose is to examine the interaction pattern between/within the High and Low groups. This gives us the odds ratio for the likelihood of between/within High and Low group interaction (tabulated in Table 3).

Table 3, (a) has the largest value in the upper left corner. The odds ratio is 1.72 for a tie within the High group, but is 0.75–0.87 for a High–Low, Low–High or Low–Low tie. Highly globalised cities do not like to tie with their national companions unless they are also highly globalised. Put concretely, New York likes to connect to Los Angeles, but not to a less globalised city such as Salt Lake City. This New York–Los Angeles tie seems contradictory to WCT’s hypothesis that more globally connected cities tend to disconnect from their national companions. Nevertheless, New York ‘may regard’ Los Angeles as another global city rather than a common national companion, connecting with it in order to increase its global ties. Based on this assumption, the high likelihood of a New York–Los Angeles connection is yet additional evidence that world cities like to connect with each other. Only the odds ratio of the New York–Salt Lake City connection will reflect the extent to which world cities like to connect with their national companions. A score below 1, as we obtained, shows the tendency of aversion. More globalised cities tend to avoid less globalised cities, and the finding provides evidence for WCT’s disarticulation hypothesis.

Model 2 examines the covariate effect of world city outdegree centrality controlling for urban population and network effects. Compared with indegree, outdegree has a weaker effect in general, indicating that the world city status assessed through receiving branch offices from other cities (i.e. indegree) rather than establishing subsidiaries in other cities (i.e. outdegree) is more important for national city network restructuring. Of three outdegree covariate effects, only the similarity effect is significantly positive. It indicates that the increase in a city’s global city status through establishing more subsidiaries in other cities will not help the city become more active or more popular, but will make it more likely to connect with others like it. Taking into account the three effects (i.e. ego, alter and similarity) simultaneously, (b) in Table 3 finds similar patterns for outdegree, as for indegree, although to a lesser extent. The odds ratio is 1.27 for a tie within the High group, but is 0.92–0.95 for a High–Low, Low–High or Low–Low tie. If by disconnection from the national companion the WCT is specifically referring to the connection between High and Low groups of world cities, the evidence supplied here—odds ratios smaller than 1—supports the WCT’s hypothesis.

In summary, more globalised cities in the US prefer to connect with others like them, with an odds ratio of 1.25–1.72, but avoid less globalised ones, with an odds ratio of 0.75–0.92. Only the connection between highly globalised cities and less globalised cities is able truly to reflect the extent to which world cities like to connect with their national companions. Therefore, the smaller than 1 odds ratio we obtained supports the WCT’s hypothesis that, as world cities become more globally connected, they tend to weaken their national ties. As US cities represent the market-centred bourgeois world cities (MWCs), we can generally say that, as MWCs become more global, their ties with their national companions will weaken, as H1 states.

sec.title: Japan
sec.p: How would the world city–national urban system relationship develop in states such as Japan and China? This is the next question we tackle. Models 3 and 4 focus on Japan. What makes Japan different from the US is that, when controlling for urban population, neither indegree nor outdegree world city centrality has a significant covariate effect on connection changes in the Japanese flight networks. This is further verified by the interaction pattern between the High and Low groups, as shown in Table 3, (c) and (d). Taking into account ego, alter and similarity effects simultaneously gives each cell an odds ratio of almost 1 with a deviation of 0.02. The odds ratio of 1 means that the odds of a tie versus no tie are the same. (Note that the odds ratios in (d) in Table 3 are exactly the same—i.e. 0.98—because zero inflation turns the median outdegree values of both groups to zero.) This means two things. First, an increase in the world city’s global status has no effect on its connections with its national companions—the odds ratio between the High and Low groups is around 1. Secondly, cities from any of the two groups are just as likely to tie as they are not to tie. One possible explanation is that connections in the flight-generated Japanese city networks have stabilised and even declined across time, as shown by the network means and standard deviations in the descriptive statistics table (see the Appendix, Table A1).

It is interesting to note that world city centrality has no effect on connection changes in the Japanese flight networks. A strong state, Japan may have successfully buffered the impact of globalisation on the national urban system. This is more difficult in the US, where globalisation is free to penetrate the domestic city system through the laissez-faire market system. The analysis of Japanese world cities—which represent the state-centred political bureaucratic world cities (SWCs)—support H2: as SWCs become more global, their ties with their national companions will not deteriorate.

sec.title: China
sec.p: Models 5 and 6 examine another developmental state, China. Like Japan, neither indegree nor outdegree world city centrality has a significant effect on connection changes in the Chinese flight networks, either in terms of ego, alter or similarity effect. What distinguishes China from Japan is that, when taking into account ego, alter and similarity effects simultaneously, the odds ratio of the tie relation between any two groups is almost the same but larger than 1 (i.e. 1.08–1.09), as shown in (e) and (f) in Table 3. This means two things. First, the world city’s global status has no effect on its connections with its national companions. For example, the odds ratio for a tie between Shanghai and Xining—the capital of Ganxu province in the least developed part of China—is the same as a tie between Shanghai and Beijing, another highly globalised city in China. Secondly, cities are more likely to tie than not tie with each other, as indicated by the odds ratio for cities from either of the two groups (i.e. the High or Low group). This may be due to the fact that connections in the flight-generated Chinese city networks have increased across time, as shown by the network means and standard deviations in the descriptive statistics table (see the Appendix, Table A2).

In sum, the research also finds that world city centrality has no effect on connection changes in the Chinese flight networks. Chinese world cities represent another genre of world cities, the DWCs, which are world cities that are situated in a strong state and rely on an external source of capital. H3 predicts that, as DWCs become more global, their ties with their national companions will weaken, but to a lesser degree than SWCs. However, we do not find support for this hypothesis—probably because the strong Chinese state has buffered the impact of globalisation on the national urban system. Evidence from China and Japan indicates that DWCs and SWCs are more alike than different.

In conclusion, the research has found that, first, as MWCs become more globally connected, they tend to weaken their ties with their national companions. Secondly, global status has no effect on SWCs’ connection with other domestic cities. Thirdly, similarly, the global status of DWCs also has no effect on their connection with other domestic cities. DWCs and SWCs are more alike than different. This leads us to conclude that the type of state is a more important factor than the source of capital with respect to the world city deterritorialisation issue. Relying on the advanced producer service complex for their global control capacity, MWCs become sites of free interglobal city capital flows that may have nothing to do with the country’s overall national development trajectory. When a core–periphery structure rises, the liberal state of MWCs often lacks institutional capacity to prevent the structure from deepening. On the other hand, the developmental state co-ordinates the economy via a policy network which is buffered from globalisation. Moreover, a developmental state has the institutional capacity to integrate global capital flows into its own territorial accumulation trajectory, preventing an internal core–periphery structure from emerging (or deepening).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The analysis examines the relations between world cities and states at the level of the national urban system. It explores the widely held claim that, as world cities strengthen ties with each other, they will weaken their linkages with their countries’ hinterlands and national urban systems. Employing the two strategic developmental axes (domestic vs foreign capital and developmental vs laissez-faire state), the research identifies three types of world cities: market-centred bourgeois world cities (MWCs), state-centred political bureaucratic world cities (SWCs) and dual-role world cities (DWCs). Selecting country cases, the US, Japan and China, provides a different prototypical milieu for each of the three world city types. The research examines the relationship between world cities’global status and their connectivity changes in the national urban system via newly developed longitudinal network modelling, as well as flight and MNCs network data.

The research finds that, in the US, more globalised cities are more likely to connect to other more global cities, while avoiding less globalised US cities. In other words, as MWCs become more globally connected, their national ties weaken. At the same time, world city status has no significant effect on the degree of integration of the Japanese or Chinese national urban systems. The odds ratio of a tie relation between any of the two groups (i.e. the more globalised group and the less globalised one) is statistically indistinguishable. The finding that DWCs and SWCs are more alike than different leads us to conclude that the neo-liberal vs developmental state axis is a more important factor than the internal–external source of capital distinction in determining whether the world city will deterritorialise vis à vis its national city system.

Are world cities becoming ‘unhooked’ from their territorial state somehow? We found that some world cities have become disarticulated from the national city system, but this tendency of deterritorialisation has its limits. The deterritorialisation is only confined to MWCs and the developmental state in Japan and China prevents SWCs and DWCs from similar deterritorialisation. Although global capital prompts the leading city in each country to deviate from national economic interests, the consequences are limited in terms of restructuring the nation’s domestic city system. World cities’ deterritorialisation fundamentally lies in the extent to which the state governs the national economy, largely, we suppose, via the co-ordinating mechanism it employs and via the way it manages capital flows.

The current findings have important policy implications. They show that world cities—especially MWCs—are likely to engender deterritorialisation in the national urban system, as illustrated by the US case. Yet a strong developmental state can effectively buffer the adverse effects of globalisation and world cities. Once again, this points to the importance of effective state intervention in the globalisation process.

Of course, one important caveat is that we have analysed cities in only one country for each of the three prototypical world cities. Thus, for example, we (knowingly) make the risky generalisation from what we find in the US to all MWCs. Another limitation of this research is related to the longitudinal network modelling. Because the software developed can so far only deal with binary outcomes, we dichotomised the dependent network variables. As a result, a considerable amount of information about the network is lost. Future research efforts will need to include a full analysis of the valued rather than binary network ties when the necessary software is developed.

Another limitation concerns the scale of world cities. Following Alderson and Beckfield (2004), this research uses the original scale of cities that the Directory of Corporate Affiliations data supply. This scale largely confines world cities to their city limits. In recent years, however, researchers (for example, Derudder, 2006) have suggested that world cities are as large as their metropolitan areas. Therefore, one future task is to employ a larger scale of world cities to examine their relation with their national urban system.

fn.p: The distinction between external and internal capital is an ideal type, and these categories may overlap in practice. It is clear that most global capital in Tokyo is domestic; for example, in 1990, Japanese MNCs controlled 12 per cent of world FDI—most of the control functions concentrate in Tokyo—but foreign investment in Japan represented only 1 per cent of the total world stock (Hill and Kim, 2000). In contrast, New York (and London as well), is both the origin and destination for global capital—because the US is the major origin and destination country for foreign direct investment (FDI). New York City (NYC) receives about 30 per cent and 15 per cent of total US FDI in financial and professional service industries respectively (Chadwin, 1998). London hosts the entire list of the top financial and professional service multinational corporations that invest in the UK (Nachum, 2000). It is in this sense we argue that global capital in both cities is largely externally originated.

For example, the average distance of the selected 50 routes (not necessarily between cities in our dataset) in China is 1270 km, in the US 1760 km and in Japan 450 km (see http://distancecalculator.globefeed.com/Country_Distance_Calculator.asp).

Cities do not really ‘choose’, but as this is an agent-based model, it is convenient to think of cities as ‘acting’ and the observed networks are the cumulative results of their actions. In reality, cities are localities that are sites for actors and agents rather than agents or actors themselves (Harvey 1989). The changes in and between world cities largely result from actions taken by firms. For example, when firms decide where to locate their operations, the outdegree and indegree centrality of world cities will change. However, local and national governments also make decisions for cities, through regulatory practices, for example. Cities will also prosper, leading to more people flying to and from them as a result of concerted efforts by local developers such as entrepreneurs, real estate developers, local government and even media. They all have a vested interest in getting capital invested in ‘their city’ and reaping the rewards of city-based growth.
